ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: presentation skills and an idea of how to approach cs research
Guest speakers were interesting

I learned a lot through my project, not only about the material but also about what research is like. The class will teach you that picking up new skills through research is possible, even if you don't think you'll understand a certain subject at first.
Got to develop code for research
Learned research skills in the CS field, mostly focused on implementing work in complex systems.

I do not feel as though it was necessary to have class time for the CS senior project/thesis, because we learned relatively little that would actually help in our writeups and/or projects and many of us were spending enough time outside of class doing senior research.
I learned how to execute on a long term (semester long) research project.
I developed my ability to conduct a large-scale, self-guided research project while working closely with an advisor.
I think this was my first experience working with machine learning with my advisor.
Completed my senior project
I learned how to do independent research

I developed a lot of skills having to do with independent work. For example, looking through research papers to bring together information and come up with questions, troubleshooting bugs in programs, and working with open-source code.
How to plan and execute a semester long project.
Independent research skills in Computer Science. Specific to my project: Building a web application, issues in digital humanities research, data visualization.
I learned a lot by taking this course. I learned significant organization skills and research skills.
Learned how to conduct research and deep dive into a specific topic
I worked on a senior project where I learned about coding an OOP model and working with probability and statistics in sports.
The course solidified the CS knowledge of the past four years as an opportunity to implement class content towards a larger research effort or an engaging senior project.
I learned how to set goals, deliverables, and a timed scheduled for myself outside of a typical professor-curated syllabus.
How to prepare for the CS senior thesis, learned from peers about the work they're doing

The course doesn't teach you anything in particular, and you mainly learn from your chosen project (which is intended). However, it's an opportunity to do a long independent project or do research with a professor if you haven't before.
None

I was able to explore a new area of computer science which I hadn't been able to do in my regular coursework: machine learning. I also was able to customize my thesis to focus on applying computer science to personal areas of interest -- namely, education. I also learned how to write a computer science research paper, and therefore critically engage with the algorithms I was coding. Finally, I occasionally learned some tangential knowledge, like how to read computer science research papers efficiently.

I learned how to design my own research project, how to teach myself about algorithms and coding techniques, and how to "manage" a project by setting my own goals and deadlines, etc. This course is definitely self-led, and my advisor was just there to answer any questions I had or help me if I was struggling. For my specific project, I learned some about Android programming, solving the TSP problem, and a bit about 2D graphics/drawing on Android.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The proposal and midterm progress presentations were great, I quite liked those. Poster presentation was okay -- I got put in one of the "side rooms" where no one really came to interact, so it wasn't that great. The in-person class requirement is fun if you use it to go to other people's presentations -- but the actual classes past the first one weren't as interesting/useful (in my opinion).

There is extremely little guidance when it comes to understanding the course requirements. Students all seem clueless as to what they're actually supposed to supply in terms of the progress reports, final reports, etc. I do not understand why this is the case: should this not be an opportunity for students to learn how to approach academic research? Obviously research has a natural degree of freedom to it, but I feel that there should be a more identifiable standard when it comes to most students' first independent report. Early lectures were wasted on things like how to read academic literature or how to use Google Scholar when they could've been spent going over what the expectations were for literature review.
the ethics lesson was rather basic but I'm glad we had one. I wish we had more information on how to submit our final reports and code in a nicely formatted way
The in-person aspects of this class just felt like busy work

Some of the meetings were helpful and the course structure allows for flexibility for students and their advisors. However, there is little guidance on how to do a project independently and how students should select and interact with their advisor, so students who are new to independent research projects may have difficulty getting organized and selecting a project that they are confident they can do well.
Don't think that the presentations are necessary
I did not find the "class" aspect of this course useful. I think it would be stronger if students were just doing research.

Strength: this class builds community for the CS department since most CS students never spend time in a single room with each other and aren't super aware of what other people are working on.
Weakness: we learned very little that would actually be useful in our projects and writeups. Also, there was relatively little support for my friends who were struggling with their projects and had advisors that were either unavailable or extremely difficult to work with.
Interesting guest lectures. Also great opportunity to work with knowledgeable staff on state-of-the-art projects.

strengths: research component, advisor relationship, self-directedness
weaknesses: did not gain much from in-person component
I think sometimes the class felt disorganized.

Strengths: An opportunity to build community in the CS department among seniors. Honestly, a pretty well done senior project class. Weaknesses: Some lectures seemed a little unnecessary to attend (the presentations among students seemed the most important)
I got to pursue a field I was highly interested in with my professor. It was a highly rewarding opportunity

The strength of the course is that it tests the independence of a student to do computer science work. The main weakness is that there are poor systems set up for communication. There were plenty of times where I had questions to ask about logistics, but my emails went unanswered and my only option was to ask other students. If I'm looking for logistic information about the course, I shouldn't have to resort to asking other students. This class needs an Ed discussion page to source common questions and concerns from students.

Strength: freedom to choose what you want with the right advisor
Weakness: not really many restrictions or standards on what you need to make.

Strengths: I enjoyed being able to formulate a project of my own; it was a nice change of pace from the structured classes that make up most of the Computer Science major. 

Weaknesses: I would have liked a little more guidance on writing the final report (for instance, a few examples of exemplary student papers). Additionally, it was initially unclear what the additional requirements were for a group project (I had worked with a partner on this project). Unless the intention is to leave most requirements up to the individual advisers, I think it would be helpful to have clearly written requirements for students who are working collaboratively.

I think 490 isn't as engaging as it should be, but what Sohee is doing is definitely on the right track! I will say, my biggest gripe is that the schedule makes very little sense. I think that students figuring their project/advisors too late. A "pitch" of available projects should be recorded by professors and made available on the Canvas page before the semester begins. Then the proposal and proposal presentation can be done sooner. The midterm presentation is far too late into the semester and too close to the deadline for the final posters.
Strengths: good way to learn something you are interested in. Weaknesses: none
Strengths: 1:1 attention from a brilliant advisor and ability to choose your own project. Weakness: none
I liked the way that the course allowed me to focus on my project, and didn't have extra work and very few class attendance requirements.
Should not have required attendance

The structure and deadlines of the course were integral for project completion and its strongest component. The ethics component of the course was super interesting and seeing more of those classes would be beneficial for future iterations.

I think having students talk to one another about research interests as well as have professors explain their strengths/fields of interest in the semesters prior could be more helpful for students who don't have a guiding idea for their senior project.

I thought that having this course to structure and frame the senior thesis around was very helpful. I'm not sure how much it benefitted students in terms of the actual lectures that happened, but it was nice to see and hear about the work that other people were doing.

I think that the attendance requirement is not helpful. I had to miss out on lab meetings and other time that I could have spent working on my thesis for lectures that were frankly not that helpful for me in the completion of my thesis or my interest in CS in general.
Fewer mandatory classes.

I enjoyed learning what other CS majors were working on throughout the semester, however, the structure of the class isn't really conducive to attendance. The topics are not super relevant to anyone's project, and since presentations were always split into multiple groups at once, we weren't even able to learn about many other projects. Also, if projects are presented in different rooms, I would prefer rooms to have projects of different areas. It seemed like everyone in a room would be presenting similar topics or have the same advisor, which isn't too interesting.
This class is stupid. It forces students to work in a lab which they may not want to do

I actually did appreciate some of the class requirements (e.g., presentations + final poster) because I felt that it kept me somewhat on track throughout the semester to complete the final report. Some of the class lectures at the beginning didn't feel very substantive though, which is unfortunate because there is an attendance requirement for the course. I did enjoy listening to other students' presentations though!
I really enjoyed my own senior project, the the course requirements (especially having to do them twice) added a lot of extra busy work and actively detracted from my senior project experience.

Strengths: keeping us on track on our theses. The deadlines throughout the semester of submitting thesis ideas, doing a midterm presentation, and a final presentation, really did keep us on track. I also appreciated the lax in-person requirements (only needing to attend 3 classes), and the guest speakers that came in to speak. I also like that it added an extra course credit to our senior year schedule. I would definitely keep it!

I think this course is pretty much perfect as-is. You only have to attend 3-4 in-person class sessions, which is definitely enough. A couple of the guest lectures seemed interesting. Other than that it's just you working on your project freely. Advisors are helpful and nice.
The biggest weakness by far was the lack of feedback--I didn't receive any feedback or comments on my project. At least a brief blurb or comment from advisors should be mandatory.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: You have to take it as a CPSC major. It's pretty fun if you pick a project that you're passionate about, and are lucky enough to have an advisor in that field that's fun to work with.
well, it's a major requirement. make sure you commit to communicating with your advisor regularly
Yes, if you are passionate about research or want to learn about a new topic that is not taught in a specific course at Yale.
Yeah, you have to do it but if you choose to work on a good project it's really fun and interesting
Not really a choice! But I liked doing research more in other semesters without the extra fluff.

If this class is something you have to take make sure that you choose an advisor who is supportive of you and has a good communication style. That is a huge factor in whether or not you have a decent time with your final project/research.
Yes, need it to graduate
Would recommend to CS majors. The course is what you make it.
I am not sure the course was helpful but I did enjoy working on my thesis.
It's required for the major, so yes
It is a senior requirement
Required for major
This is a required course for the major, but overall I think it was a good experience.
Well you have to take it, so... yeah... I guess?
Yes
It is required for the CS major
It's a requirement for the major, so I'd recommend it.
Yes! As an EECS major, the structure this class offered was much appreciated. The EE major didn't have anything equivalent unless if I was ABET.
Yup, pick a good advisor and put in the work.
Yes, since it's required to graduate and is self-structured so it prepares one well for other personal projects.
It's necessary for the CS major, so yes. I would take it in the Fall if possible.
You have to take it, but it's ultimately your choice on what you want to get out of it.
No there should be another option for cs majors

Obviously this course is required for the CS degree, but the experience is very advisor-dependent, as you might expect. Make sure to spend the time at the beginning of the semester looking for advisors and settling on a project that seems both feasible and rewarding, as that will likely determine your overall satisfaction with the course. The deliverables can seem annoying at first, but I actually thought that the presentations kept me somewhat on track throughout the semester, which is helpful for a class that is so independently-driven. The class lectures at the beginning were pretty dull, which is frustrating because of the attendance requirements, but I found that listening to other students' presentations was interesting!
Its required. I would recommend the faculty put together a better option for year-long cs theses.

Yes, because it is required to get a CS degree, and also, because it is one of those rare opportunities that allows you to explore an area of CS with all its infinite possibilities and applications to other fields.

You're probably only taking this course to fulfill the senior requirement. If you're someone who has an idea for a creative research project or just likes to explore new topics in-depth, I'd strongly recommend this course regardless of whether it's required. You'll learn a lot as long as you're engaged and interested in your project and have time to put into it.
